blips.name: Microservices
blips.description:
A microservices architecture consists of a collection of small, autonomous services. Each service is self-contained and should implement a single business capability within a bounded context. A bounded context is a natural division within a business and provides an explicit boundary within which a domain model exists.

We've successfully adopted this architectural style on several projects and while it has a lot of benefits, we should be careful with bringing the additional complexity to the system. Microservices should not be the default choice for architecture, mainly because many organizations and systems are lacking the foundations in terms of continuous delivery and infrastructure automation.

Useful links:
  • Microservices architecture style
  • Microservices architecture introduction

blips.name: Infrastructure as code
blips.description:
Infrastructure as code is an approach where infrastructure configuration is scripted or described by files that are stored in version control, and changes are pushed out to the data center in a controlled manner.

Using this approach provides consistent and repeatable environment changes, reducing the manual effort involved, especially in troubleshooting environmental differences.

Useful links:
  • What is Infrastrcture as code?
  • IaC Best practices

blips.name: Pipelines as code
blips.description:
The pipelines as code technique emphasizes that the configuration of delivery pipelines that build, test and deploy our applications or infrastructure should be treated as code; they should be placed under source control and modularized in reusable components with automated testing and deployment.

We've adopted this technique on several projects and we strongly recommend to have this into consideration when planning to build any kind of CI/CD.

Useful links:
  • Pipelines as code

blips.name: Feature flags
blips.description:
The idea behind feature flags is to build conditional feature branches into code in order to make logic available only to certain groups of users at a time. If the flag is “on,” new code is executed, if the flag is “off,” the code is skipped.

By our experience, unless you need A/B testing or canary release or hand over feature release responsibility to the business, we encourage you to use the simplest possible feature toggle instead of unnecessarily complex feature toggle frameworks.

Useful links:
  • Feature toggles
  • What are feature flags?

Miki Jovanovski

blips.name: Event-Driven Architecture
blips.description:
An event-driven architecture consists of event producers that generate a stream of events, and event consumers that listen for the events. Events are delivered in near real time, so consumers can respond immediately to events as they occur. Producers are decoupled from consumers — a producer doesn't know which consumers are listening. Consumers are also decoupled from each other, and every consumer sees all of the events.

While it provides great decoupling and high scalability, on the project's we've used brought a lot of challenges as well, like when to validate (before the event is raised or after), ordering of event handling, idempotency and complexity around event registration and handlers.

Useful links:
  • Event-Driven architecture style
  • What is an Event-Driven architecture

Anastasija Jovanoska

blips.name: Serverless Architecture
blips.description:
Serverless architecture replaces long-running virtual machines with ephemeral compute power that comes into existence on request and disappears immediately after use. This architecture can mitigate some security concerns such as security patching and SSH access control, and can make much more efficient use of compute resources. These systems cost very little to operate and can have inbuilt scaling features.

While all the benefits, this architecture style has a lot of challenges and is definitely not suitable for APIs (we've seen this with .NET and Java runtimes). The reason for this is mainly the startup latency (cold start), memory limits and execution duration. Although there are approaches to improve startup time (provisioned concurrency), it can be quite expensive. Good example of usage non HTTP Lambdas are SQS/SNS/EventBridge events, using "cron" expression to execute some logic in certain time (period).

Useful links:
  • Serverless Architectures
  • Serverless architecture considerations
  • Choose the right FaaS solution

blips.name: Microfrontends
blips.description:
The idea behind Micro Frontends is to think about a website or web app as a composition of features which are owned by independent teams. Each team has a distinct area of business or mission it cares about and specializes in. A team is cross functional and develops its features end-to-end, from database to user interface.

Although we've used this on several projects, concerning is the tendency to use this architecture as an excuse to mix a range of competing technologies, tools or frameworks in a single page, leading to micro frontend anarchy. A particularly egregious form of this syndrome is using multiple frontend frameworks — for example, React.js and Angular — in the same "single-page" application. Although this might be technically possible, it is far from advisable when not part of a deliberate transition strategy.

  • Microfrontends

blips.name: Service mesh
blips.description:
Service mesh is an approach to operating a secure, fast and reliable microservices ecosystem. It has been an important stepping stone in making it easier to adopt microservices at scale. It offers discovery, security, tracing, monitoring and failure handling. It provides these cross-functional capabilities without the need for a shared asset such as an API gateway or baking libraries into each service. A typical implementation involves lightweight reverse-proxy processes, aka sidecars, deployed alongside each service process in a separate container. Sidecars intercept the inbound and outbound traffic of each service and provide cross-functional capabilities mentioned above.

We are looking for a project/POC in order to assess this in more depth.

blips.name: Architectural fitness function
blips.description:
Borrowed from evolutionary computing, a fitness function is used to summarize how close a given design solution is to achieving the set aims. An architectural fitness function, as defined in Building Evolutionary Architectures, provides an objective integrity assessment of some architectural characteristics, which may encompass existing verification criteria, such as unit testing, metrics, monitors, and so on.

We've managed to have some fitness functions on some projects for code quality, but we are looking for a project/POC where we can assess this in more depth, so any volunteers for this initiative are welcomed.

blips.name: Remote mob programming
blips.description:
Remote mob programming allows teams to quickly “mob” around an issue or piece of code without the physical constraints of only being able to fit so many people around a pairing station. Teams can quickly collaborate on an issue or piece of code using their video conferencing tool of choice without having to connect to a big display, book a physical meeting room or find a whiteboard.

blips.name: Deep Learning
blips.description:
Deep Learning is a subfield of machine learning concerned with algorithms inspired by the structure and function of the brain called artificial neural networks. It's a technique that teaches computers to do what comes naturally to humans: learn by example.

We are currently working on Sign Language educational app. The app lets you learn the Sign Language, starting with numbers and colors, using a deep learning model to verify if you are correctly making the gestures.

blips.description:
Azure Pipelines is a product of Azure DevOps that offers cloud-based solutions to implement pipelines as code for projects hosted in Azure DevOps Git server or other Git solution such as GitHub or Bitbucket. The interesting part of this solution is the ability to run your scripts in Linux, MacOS and Windows agents without the overhead of managing a virtual machine on your own.

We've successfully used Azure Pipelines on multiple projects across the company, It is a mature platform, offering agents, artifacts, a lot of options and it is constantly upgraded by Microsoft.

blips.description:
Jenkins is an open source automation server which enables developers around the world to reliably build, test, and deploy their software.

We've used Jenkins on multiple projects within the company. Although it can be very useful, it is open source and free, it can become difficult to maintain with all it's plugins. However, we should be careful, because Jenkins continues to model pipelines using plugins and fails to change the core Jenkins product to model pipelines directly, which is better as we've seen with other platforms.

blips.name: Azure App Service
blips.description:
Azure App Service is an HTTP-based service for hosting web applications, REST APIs, and mobile back ends. You can develop in your favorite language, be it .NET, .NET Core, Java, Ruby, Node.js, PHP, or Python. Applications run and scale with ease on both Windows and Linux-based environments.

Our experience with Azure App Services is great - it not only adds the power of Microsoft Azure to your application, such as security, load balancing, autoscaling, and automated management, but also you can also take advantage of its DevOps capabilities, such as continuous deployment from Azure DevOps, GitHub, Docker Hub, and other sources, package management, staging environments, custom domain and TLS/SSL certificates.

blips.name: Azure Functions
blips.description:
Azure Functions is a cloud service available on-demand that provides all the continually updated infrastructure and resources needed to run your applications. You focus on the pieces of code that matter most to you, and Functions handles the rest. Functions provides serverless compute for Azure. You can use Functions to build web APIs, respond to database changes, process IoT streams, manage message queues etc.

We've had a lot of experience with Azure Functions (and Azure Durable functions that are orchestrating other functions) on one of our projects. It has certain challenges around networking, memory consumption, cold starts, but it still provides a great way to build your infrastructure - they are the usually the pipes moving data between different Azure services.

blips.name: Azure SQL Database
blips.description:
Azure SQL Database is a fully managed platform as a service (PaaS) database engine that handles most of the database management functions such as upgrading, patching, backups, and monitoring without user involvement. Azure SQL Database is always running on the latest stable version of the SQL Server database engine and patched OS with 99.99% availability.

We've used this on multiple projects successfully and it is a recommended approach for SQL Server infrastructure. However, please check the limitations if you're using some specific feature like cross-DB queries etc. before you move your infrastructure to the Cloud.

  • Azure SQL Database Overview

blips.name: Azure Load Testing
blips.description:
Azure Load Testing enables developers nd testers to generate high-scale load and run simulations that reveal actionable insights into app performance, scalability, and capacity with a fully managed load-testing service. You can get started quickly using existing Apache JMeter scripts (can reuse JMeter files), gain specialized recommendations backed by comprehensive metrics and analytics, and support continuous improvement through automated continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) workflows—all with a testing service built for Azure. You can also automate regression testing by running load tests as part of your continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) workflow.

We've looking for a project where we can use this platform to perform load-testing. However, this is still in preview, so changes are expected in the upcoming period.

blips.name: Azure Application Insights
blips.description:
Azure Application Insights is a feature of Azure Monitor that provides extensible application performance management (APM) and monitoring for live web apps. It can auto-detect performance anomalies, helps diagnose issues by using powerful analytics tools, shows what users actually do with apps, continuously helps improving the app performance and usability, supports a wide variety of platforms -.NET, Node.js, Java, Python, works for apps hosted on-premises, hybrid, or on any public cloud, is integrated with DevOps processes, has connection points (SDK) to many development tools and supports custom telemetry.

We are extensively using Application INsights to all our Azure apps and it is strongly recommended that we continue using it in future.

blips.name: Azure Logic Apps
blips.description:
Azure Logic Apps is a cloud-based platform for creating and running automated workflows that integrate your apps, data, services, and systems. With this platform, you can quickly develop highly scalable integration solutions for your enterprise and business-to-business (B2B) scenarios.

We're currently working with Logic Apps on one of our projects. It helps to coordinate the flow of data through disparate systems. Logic Apps works best when you are integrating multiple services with some added control logic.

blips.name: AWS Lambda
blips.description:
AWS Lambda is a serverless computing service provided by Amazon Web Services (AWS). Users of AWS Lambda create functions, self-contained applications written in one of the supported languages and runtime, and upload them to AWS Lambda, which executes those functions in an efficient and flexible manner.

We've used Lambdas on several projects and we can freely say that they are becoming better since AWS is investing a lot in them. However, we should be careful for which purpose are we using them due to their disadvantages like cold start, package & memory limits and cost. From our experience so far, writing Lambda functions in C# and Java is not a good choice (issues with cold starts, which can be couple of seconds depending on the package size and dependencies). On the other side, Lambdas can be very useful for non-HTTP events, like SQS, SQS, EventBridge, CronJobs etc. (where cold start is not crucial).

blips.name: AWS OpenSearch (ElasticSearch)
blips.description:
Amazon OpenSearch Service (successor to Amazon Elasticsearch Service) is a managed service that makes it easy to deploy, operate, and scale OpenSearch clusters in the AWS Cloud. Amazon OpenSearch Service supports OpenSearch and legacy Elasticsearch OSS. When you create a cluster, you have the option of which search engine to use.

We've been using this on one of our projects with great success, but we need to be careful around costs vs using a standalone ElasticSearch instance (i.e. on EC2). We need to pay by the hour according to rates that vary per instance type and AWS region. AWS OpenSearch (Elasticsearch) comes prepackaged with a limited set of plugins that we are unable to modify or expand. Even with the advantages the AWS Elasticsearch provides in being easy to set up and lowering the operational aspects of managing our Elasticsearch clusters, we will still need expert knowledge to manage day-to-day operations.

blips.name: AWS ElastiCache
blips.description:
Amazon ElastiCache is a fully managed, in-memory caching service supporting flexible, real-time use cases. You can use ElastiCache for caching, which accelerates application and database performance, or as a primary data store for use cases that don't require durability like session stores, gaming leaderboards, streaming, and analytics. ElastiCache is compatible with Redis and Memcached.

As fully-managed AWS service it has a lot of benefits for the application's performance and it is has high availability and scalability. However we can only connect it to databases and applications that are hosted by Amazon. The user interface itself is not very intuitive, and its many options might feel a bit overwhelming when we’re getting started. Also, the costs here can add up quickly over time.

blips.name: MongoDB
blips.description:
MongoDB is a source-available cross-platform document-oriented database program. Classified as a NoSQL database program, MongoDB uses JSON-like documents with optional schemas.

MongoDB is far and away the most popular of the NoSQL databases. Its document data model gives developers great flexibility, while its distributed architecture allows for great scalability. We've used it successfully on several projects.

PostgreSQL supports advanced data types and performance optimization features, which are only available in expensive commercial databases, like Oracle and SQL Server.

We are using SQL Server on several project and apart from it's cost and licensing, it provides a lot of flexibility, an abundance of functionalities and opportunities and it is considered as the best RDBMS.

blips.name: Bitbucket Pipelines
blips.description:
Bitbucket Pipelines is an integrated CI/CD service built into Bitbucket. It allows you to automatically build, test, and even deploy your code based on a configuration file in your repository.

We've used this on one of our projects. Bitbucket pipeline uses YAML to config the pipeline (there is no UI). It uses an image to run each step inside the docker container. Each step runs in a separate docker container to run the script. There is a separate "Deployments" section which allows deployment (promotion) to multiple environments. One disadvantage is that we cant store data for our pipeline reliably. With the pipeline working off a docker image we get a fresh image each time, any data created on the last pipeline is lost unless it is cached. However caches are lost after 7 days and may be lost at any time so we need to ensure the pipeline can work with or without them. This means any test that outputs files or had files for a baseline will only work if we have them in a remote location and have them brought in when needed.

blips.name: Kubernetes
blips.description:
Kubernetes (K8s) is an open-source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications. It enables easy deployment and management of applications with microservice architecture. Additionally, it provides a framework to run distributed systems resiliently with great predictability.

We've used Kubernetes on several projects and the experience was good. The Cloud providers are offering managed solutions where we only need to care about our application and all administration is out-of-the-box. It has quickly become the default solution for most of our clients when deploying containers into a cluster of machines. However, it requires good management of resources and we need to be careful especially when multiple independent apps are running in the same Kubernetes cluster.

blips.name: AWS Cognito
blips.description:
Amazon Cognito lets you add user sign-up, sign-in, and access control to your web and mobile apps quickly and easily. Amazon Cognito scales to millions of users and supports sign-in with social identity providers, such as Apple, Facebook, Google, and Amazon, and enterprise identity providers via SAML 2.0 and OpenID Connect.

We've used Cognito successfully on several projects and it is a good choice for quick implementation of your user authentication, however if your application does not use AWS, connecting it with 3rd party services will take time and requires customization. Also, if using Cognito API, it has limitations on some APIs and if we plan to use it extensively we can receive "throttle" errors. For one of the projects there was Active Directory which we connected with SAML auth, but the whole process of configuration and set up was pretty complex and time consuming.

blips.name: AWS DynamoDB
blips.description:
DynamoDB is a key-value and document database with single-digit millisecond response times at any scale. Its a fully managed durable database with built-in security, backup, and restore capabilities.

We've used DynamoDB on one project and it offers a lot of benefits. Very interesting feature is that DynamoDB supports streams, allowing other systems to react to data changes (similar to SQL triggers). However, we should be careful with the very weak querying model. Primarily, it doesn't allow for traditional SQL queries and access patterns, which means for things like free-text search or ad-hoc queries, we'll likely need to export data to a different system. Also, we need to model our data differently than you're used to with an RDBMS. In terms of costs, since we're paying per usage, it's often hard to predict when that usage might spike, it's not unheard of to get caught with unexpected costs.

Amazon API Gateway is a fully managed service that makes it easy for developers to create, publish, maintain, monitor, and secure APIs at any scale.

We've used this service on one of our projects and while it has a lot of benefits, it also adds latency to all our API calls. Performance degradation is a concern due to the multitude of scenarios that the API Gateway will handle and can impact the speed and reliability of our application.

We've used this service on one of our projects and while it has a lot of benefits it is hard to troubleshoot.

Amazon Kinesis offers key capabilities to cost-effectively process streaming data at any scale, along with the flexibility to choose the tools that best suit the requirements of your application.

We've successfully used this service on one of our projects.

Amazon Redshift uses SQL to analyze structured and semi-structured data across data warehouses, operational databases, and data lakes, using AWS-designed hardware and machine learning to deliver the best price performance at any scale.

GitHub Actions is a continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) platform that allows you to automate your build, test, and deployment pipeline. You can create workflows that build and test every pull request to your repository, or deploy merged pull requests to production.

We've used briefly GitHub Action as part of a DevOps Community project and the results were encouraging - it is an easy to use platform. blips.name: Azure Site Recovery
blips.description:
Site Recovery helps ensure business continuity by keeping business apps and workloads running during outages. Site Recovery replicates workloads running on physical and virtual machines (VMs) from a primary site to a secondary location. When an outage occurs at your primary site, you fail over to secondary location, and access apps from there. After the primary location is running again, you can fail back to it.

We've used Site Recovery for migration of infrastructure from on-premise to Cloud successfully. We also recommend to explore the Disaster Recovery Scenarios in order to have more knowledge of this service.

blips.name: VerneMQ
blips.description:
VerneMQ is a MQTT publish/subscribe message broker which implements the standard MQTT protocol. It is built to work as a distributed message broker and ensures continued operation in the event of node or network failures and easy horizontal scalability. It uses master-less clustering technology. MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB, Redis, and Memcached are some of the popular tools that integrate with VerneMQ.

There are probably better commercial brokers, but either more expensive (cloud), more complex to set up or not with a free license. On the other hand, this is a great broker if you want to quickly test things out. It really gets you up to speed. It has a lot of plugins, out-of-box integration with some of great tools, such as Graphite, Prometheus and Grafana and it gives an option to easily scale it using clusters with Kubernetes to handle the replicas.

They have the concept of orbs, which are reusable snippets of code that automate repetead processes, speed up project setup and integrate well with 3rd party tools. Microsoft Power Platform is a group of products offered by Microsoft to develop and build complex business solutions, analyze, and draw data visualizations, automate a business process, or build virtual agents for communication. All these products offer a platform in which no code is required to build the applications.

We've successfully built a product with Microsoft Power Platofm in the past period. The main benefits are improved development speed, no need of separate FE/BE developer, Azure AD integration out-of-the-box, cloud-ready, native data integration with build-in Dataverse database, many build-in connectors and automated deployments. The challenges we've faced are cost (per user/app), development IDE, deployments, component dependencies, managed solution managament, external users and user context in Power Automate flow.

blips.name: BurpSuite
